name: Sergi Gomez
post: "Can you please create a new dimension for this metric?"This is one of the most frequent requests that data teams get from data consumers. A simple but repetitive one that fills our backlog at the end of the day. The consequence? Data teams get overloaded with those "quick changes" and they can't focus on higher-impact tasks.Data consumers should be able to make those simple changes themselves. But if we try to force them to adopt SQL/dbt, it won't fly, trust me. Yes, they will give it a try but, after a few weeks, they'll get back to creating a new JIRA ticket.If we want this habit to stick, we have to make it easier, and, whenever possible, allow them to work on the tool that they already use Every, Single, Day: Excel / Google Sheets.Google Sheets are the ideal medium when we need to create a new dimension that is simply the mapping from an existing one.Example: "I want a new dimension called Product Category as a higher-level dimension of Product Name"I constantly see data models full of "CASE WHEN X THEN Y". Please, don't do that!Instead, the following is a very very simple but efficient method to do it much faster and that provides way more control & autonomy for end users:(I'll use the example of Product Category -> Product Name for sake of illustration):1- Create a new table on Google Sheets with all Product Name values - Note: You should as well include all Primary Keys (e.g. product ID) to avoid issues such as duplicates. 2- Create a new column (Product Category) and ask the data consumer to do the mapping.3- Integrate this table into your Data Warehouse (DW) using Airbyte. Making this connection on Airbyte has a bit of heavy lifting (service accounts, keys...), and there may be tools that make it easier, (maybe we should try Portable, Ethan Aaron? ğŸ™‚ ). Note that you won't need Airbyte if you use BigQuery as DW. BigQuery already provides seamless Google Sheets integration. 4- Add the new dimensions to the corresponding dbt model with a simple join operation, and run the dbt models - (run some tests to make sure there aren't duplicates!)VoilÃ , the new dimension is available on the BI. And the best thing: If data consumers want to make any changes to this dimension, they can do it themselves and it will be automatically updated on the BI! ğŸ˜ Watch the demo if you want to see how to do itğŸ‘‡. There is a big list of examples for which this method is very handy:- Create a new dimension that indicates the validity of an order based on other dimensions, so end users can later on filter out non-valid orders for your Revenue metrics ğŸ˜‰ - Create a new dimension that gives a name to an identifier (i.e. a number). So instead of distributor_id you can have the distributor name - ...At Saivo, we love making data teams' life easier by empowering data consumers to do these simple tasks themselves. It's a win-win formula.Would love to get your feedback! #nocode #dbt #datanalytics #businessanalyst

Once you have a clear picture of that, and the factors that may influence it, you can begin to dive deeper into it and its potential solutions.How to Improve:Â When faced with a new situation, question, or scenario, stop to take a mental picture of how things are stacked up.2. ASK QUESTIONSâ€œIt is better to debate a question without settling it than to settle a question without debating itâ€ â€” Joseph JoubertLearn to question everything. Itâ€™s very easy to accept things at face value, but thatâ€™s a sign of a lazy mind.How to Improve:Â You can start by asking the following questions:What do you already know?How do you know that?What seems to be the reason for this happening?What are you trying to prove, disprove, demonstrate, critique, and support?What are you overlooking?You should continually go back to these basic questions you asked when you set out to solve the problem. These types of questions urge you to get right to the core of a problem, examining it for simple solutions before assuming its complexities.3. BE AWARE OF YOUR MENTAL PROCESSBeing a good critical thinker requires you to accept that you have biases. Although even the best critical thinkers will never be entirely bias-free, you need to learn to look out for them.How to Improve: Make a habit of asking yourself what youâ€™re assuming and why youâ€™re assuming that, and check for things like stereotyping.Becoming more mindful of your own biases is the first step to rewriting these parts of your thinking.4. post: We did it! We just cycled from Helsinki to Singapore!â€¢ 21 countriesâ€¢ 15400kmâ€¢ 245 daysWhy in the world would we cycle to Singapore?We wanted to go on an adventure. Alvari had cycled from Helsinki to France and liked it. We looked at a map and Singapore seemed like a nice peninsula at the very end of continental Asia. We wanted to break daily routines, to do some house cleaning of our minds, to slow time down, to rid ourselves of living for the future, to challenge ourselves both phyiscally and mentally. And we did just that!Words fall short to capture the emotions of yesterday, so here are some effable learnings from life on the saddle:1. The best days are the ones that seem worst in the moment. This goes for this trip and my previous jobs. The days where shit hits the fan are the ones in which you learn the most and that you will later cherish. 2.  Don't consume experiences and hope for things to play out in a hopeful way, but create your own adventures with the resources you have available and make things happen.  3. Expect nothing. Focus on the process, not the outcome. 4. Finland is quite a special country where things really work well and the quality of life is extremely high. I easily fall into routines and comfort, so remember to continue to challenge yourself and don't fall into the traps of comfort and pleasure.  5. Stay active. The most physical days seem to provide the most insight and feelings of tranquility. 6. It doesn't really help what you want to do in the future, just give 100% to what you are doing now and it will open doors for you later on. Less planning, more living. name: Danny Butvinik
post: In data science and machine learning, the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm can be used to estimate latent variables, like those that come from mixture distributions (we know that they came from a mixture but donâ€™t know from which specific distribution).Â The EM algorithm is a specialized approach for Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) problems. It has some nice features, like not needing to know the size of each step and always converging to a local maximum of the likelihood function under simple conditions.Â Although MLE and EM can both find the best-fit parameters, the ways they find the models are very different. Â MLE gathers all the information first, then uses that information to build the most likely model. Â EM makes guesses about the parameters to account for the missing data. It then changes the model to make the guesses and the real data fit together. The basic steps for the algorithm are:Â 1. The model parameters are guessed first, and a probability distribution is made. This is sometimes called the â€œE-Stepâ€ for the â€œexpectedâ€ distribution.Â 2. Newly observed data is fed into the model.Â 3. The probability distribution from the E-step is tweaked to include the new data. This is sometimes called the M-step.Â 4. Steps 2-4 are repeated until stability (i.e., a distribution that doesnâ€™t change from the E-step to M-step is reached.)Â The EM algorithm always converges, even though it might converge to bad local extrema.Â The expectation-maximization algorithm can be used:Â (*) to fill in their missing data in a sample.(*)Â as the basis for the unsupervised learning of clusters. (*) to estimate the parameters of the Hidden Markov Model (HMM). (*) to discover the values of latent variables.Â LimitationÂ The EM algorithm can be very slow, even on the fastest computer. It works best when you only have a small percentage of missing data and the dimensionality of the data isnâ€™t too large. The E-step moves more slowly as the number of dimensions goes up. The E-step may move very slowly if you have data with many dimensions, as the procedure approaches a local maximum.Â Image: Author (inspired by Victor Lavrenko)#machinelearning #datascience

name: hashtag#data
post: Hype, hyperbole!That's the current trajectory the data industry is on.Why?I was just speaking to a COO about the data and digital revolution.He stated it was just overrated and has a tendency to under deliver.We discussed his experiences and guess what like many others there was a litany of tech being rolled out with no real directional motivation.I asked what that meant "directional motivation" and he said that we have a vision in the company, we have a number of corporate objectives and none of the direction of travel really took that into consideration.He was super frustrated!He had been in many meetings where swathes of PowerPoint presentations were thrust at the attendees with too many buzzwords such as AI/IoT/ML.He had interjected many times and wanted to understand how all of it fit back to the purpose. Unfortunately, for him, the CIO was unencumbered and spending his way to "out-teching our rivals" which apparently was something actually stated in a presentation.He also commented on how little value it would provide his operational teams who were struggling with cost, supply chain issues and speed to market.We started to discuss what his thoughts were and whether he had the motivation in himself to stop the money tech train.It was an awkward moment, there was a pause, some silence between us and then a big sigh.He was planning on having it out at the C-Suite and board level.We paused and I could hear his frustrations through the ether.I've not had that candid a conversation about data and tech with someone for a while, where frustrations had got to increasingly alarming levels.I think he just wanted to speak to someone with an external viewpoint.At the same time my frustrations were at boiling point, as I have been seeing this type of approach in many organisations.He said our discussion had been cathartic.I am sure there are many others that are feeling these frustrations from a data and tech perspective.I've said it many times before - data and tech are the enablers for the business strategy. They aren't THE business strategy.Looking at it through the lens of the business is THE most powerful approach companies should take.Having a business-driven data strategy limits the shiny toy syndrome!This is a Friday frustration moment where I ask myself why are we at this point where companies would rather invest in tech instead of doing the hard work around people and process.All of the investments are useless if you can't get those two right. Don't be a follower, lead your company through transformation the hard way which ends in more success.At the end he said he felt better and thanked me for my ear.I ended the call with one question for the C-Suite and Boards:When will you start leading the pack and stop being sheep?Kyle Fred Eddie Bill Malcolm Juan Joe Joti Mark Andrew Afke#data #transformation #strategy #business #datastrategy #tech #digital #success

name: Daliana Liu
post: How to find a job during hiring freeze using Linkedin:1. In Linkedin's search bar, type in "data scientist hiring", you see a list of people with "we are hiring" in their job titles. NEVER ask them for a job directly. Do the following before you send a message.2. Research the job roles Check their profile to see if there are links to the roles they are hiring and see if it fits your background. If you can't find it, research similar roles on their company's hiring website.Don't send generic message. It's a waste of their time. Let them know you understand what kind of candidate they are looking for.3. Send a short personalized message"Hi XX, I saw that you are hiring, I have experience in XYZ and I'm interested in the role, can we chat for 15 min to me to learn more about it?"4. Follow upPeople get busy. If they don't reply, follow up after a few days. Create a spreadsheet to track your messages like your 'job search Salesforce'.Maybe after you chat, they are not hiring or they don't think you are a good fit but want to stay connected; follow up after a few months when you feel you are more ready for the role.80% of the success is in the follow up.5. Use the relevant Linkedin headlineMake sure your Linkedin headline is the type of role you are looking for. For example, if your previous role's business title was "finance researcher" but your actual role was like a data scientist in finance.Then, if you are looking for data scientist roles and have the skillset and experience, change your headline to "data scientist", which is easier for recruiters to find you. With the hiring freeze, it's harder to find a job. And just because it's hard, you should be more thoughtful and strategic about networking. Before you send a message, read it and think whether people on the receiving side would like to read it.What are your advice in job search right now?*I write more about data science career at www.dalianaliu.com free to subscribe#datascienceÂ #career
